awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences (ECS) Program in the Division of Chemistry.  Professor Barbara Finlayson-Pitts and her group at the University of California-Irvine (UCI) study the environmental fate of neonicotinoid pesticides. There has been a significant, recent, worldwide decline in bees, which play a major role in pollination. Neonicotinoid pesticides have been implicated in this decline, along with other factors such as parasites and pathogens, loss of habitat and diversity of pollinators. Neonicotinoid pesticides have low toxicity to mammals.  However, in the atmosphere they may undergo transformations to form new products that are more toxic than the parent compounds.  The goals of this project are to elucidate the atmospheric reactions of neonicotinoids, the rate at which they are changed into other molecules in the environment, and the nature of the resultant molecules.  The results of this research will contribute to a molecular level understanding of the atmospheric lifetimes and fates of neonicotinoid pesticides in the environment.  The data collected enable scientists to establish the risk assessments for these compounds. Training in current techniques for studying heterogenous chemistry on surfaces is provided to a diverse group of students and postdoctoral fellows.  


The goal of this research is to provide a molecular level understanding of the photochemistry of surface-bound neonicotinoid insecticides (NNs) and their reactions with trace atmospheric gaseous oxidants. NNs have found increasing use since their first introduction about 25 years ago, largely as seed coatings and soil treatments.  Their reactions once in the atmosphere are not well known.  This project studies the photochemistry and atmospheric reactions of seven commonly used neonicotinoids which are nitroguanidines (imidacloprid, thiamethoxam, clothianidin and dinotefuran), cyanamidines (thiacloprid and acetamiprid) or nitromethylenes (nitenpyram).  The quantum yields for photolysis of the compounds that absorb light at wavelengths relevant to the atmosphere are measured. Also, both the gas phase and solid state products are determined using a variety of techniques. These techniques include attenuated total reflectance and transmission Fourier transform infrared spectrometry and several mass spectrometry techniques. The identity and yields of the products and the kinetics of oxidation by ozone, the hydroxyl radical and the nitrate radical are measured. This is used for a quantitative assessment of the atmospheric lifetimes and fates of neonicotinoids in air.Professor Finlayson-Pitts' is the Co-Director of AirUCI, a collaborative group of faculty at UCI that sponsors a number of educational initiatives, including student research retreats, training in effective communication and discussions of career options.  Collaborations and hosting international visitors provides breadth of experience and networking opportunities to group members.

por.por_cntn:
Neonicotinoid pesticides (NNs) are in widespread use globally, having supplanted many of the more toxic pesticides used in the past. A common use is as seed coatings, where they get taken up systemically as the plant grows and are available to insects such as aphids that attack the plant surfaces. They also end up on soil and dust, and thus become widely distributed.  An advantage of the NNs is their lower mammalian toxicity, but their use has been associated with the loss of pollinators and bee colony collapse. An accurate environmental assessment of their impacts requires understanding their fates in air and water, and the potential for formation of more toxic products.  

 In this research, we measured the lifetimes of commonly used NNs with respect to light absorption at the Earth’s surface, as well as with respect to their reactions with two ubiquitous atmospheric oxidants, ozone and the hydroxyl radical. The lifetimes of solid NN (as might occur on plant surfaces) with respect to light absorption varied from half an hour to 10-16 hours, depending on the particular NN.  One of the NN, nitenpyram (NPM), exhibited a large shift in the wavelengths of light it absorbed in water compared to the solid, and the efficiency of the decomposition increased, leading to an estimated lifetime of only 5 min in water! A surprising product for those with a particular structural feature (nitroguanidines) was nitrous oxide, which is a greenhouse gas. One of the solid products of light absorption by imidacloprid has been shown by others to have increased mammalian toxicity compared to the parent compound, illustrating the need to understand the products as well as the parent pesticide.

 In addition to the pure NNs, we studied some of the commercial formulations as well since they contain a variety of constituents that could in principle alter the photochemistry of the NN’s.  However, we found no data suggesting this was the case, thus validating the use of the pure compounds in studies of their environmental fates.

NPM has a double bond and hence is reactive towards ozone. High molecular mass products that did not contain oxygen were identified; this is highly unusual for an oxidation reaction, particularly by ozone. The reaction also generated nitrous acid, which is a source of the hydroxyl radical in air.

 Studies of reactions of three solid NNs (imidacloprid, dinotefuran and clothianidin) with the hydroxyl radical showed the formation of a variety of products, some of which have increased toxicity compared to the parent compounds. Their lifetimes with respect to typical OH concentrations are estimated to be in the range of 10-17 days, similar to the photolysis lifetimes. Further reactions of the initially formed products were also observed, suggesting that not only the degradation of the parent NN needs to be taken into account, but also the further reactions of the products.

Finally, studies of the reactions of a series of simple model compounds for the NN pesticides with ozone in solution were carried out. These model compounds contained the reactive functional groups of the pesticides but were much simpler in structure. We showed that the insights gained from these simple compounds could be used to predict reactivity of the more complex NPM. This suggests that structure-reactivity relationships developed using simple model compounds can be used to predict the chemistry of the much more complex NNs and similar species without having to study each compound individually.

 In short, it is critical to define the lifetimes and products of reaction in the environment of neonicotinoid (and other) pesticides in order to provide an accurate environmental assessment of their impacts. These studies have made a significant contribution to that effort.
